SUMMARY: DnaA plays an important role in initiating chromosomal replication to bind sequences in chromosomal origin. It belongs to DnaA family of transcriptional regulators. DnaA also binds to sites at datA locus and this binding serves to limit excess DnaA activity, but or DnaA-binding sites are shown not to share this function [12068813]. Regulation has been described [11483528, 9674428, 16077105]. IdaB is a member of AAA chaperone-like family of ATPases [11483528] that is required for inhibition of initiation of DNA synsis via antagonism of DnaA activity by DNA polymerase III beta subunit (sliding clamp) [9674428, 11483528]. IdaB and sliding clamp stimulate ATP hydrolysis within DnaA-ATP complex, which renders it inactive, and DNA replication activity also contributes to this downregulation [9674428]. DnaA also can inhibit gene expression of or genes such as guaA, dam, rpoH, ftsA, and mioC.
